thread.title: Malaysians travelling to India facing problems with big rupee notes
thread.title_full: Malaysians travelling to India facing problems with big rupee notes

title: Malaysians travelling to India facing problems with big rupee notes
text:
Sunday, 19 February 2017 Malaysians travelling to India facing problems with big rupee notes 
PETALING JAYA: Those travelling to India may not be able to bring the change they want as only the larger Rs2,000 (about RM133) notes are available in the country. 
This comes after more than three months since India overhauled its financial system, including scrapping some denominations and introducing new banknotes of Rs500 (about RM34) and Rs2,000. 
Global Millennium Trading staff Mazlan Sah, 19, said there had been a shortage of smaller notes – in the Rs100 (around RM7) and Rs500 deno­minations – although the Rs2,000 rupee notes were back in stock. 
He said there had been issues with availability since the old Rs500 and Rs1,000 notes were removed from circulation in November. 
“People don’t want the big notes. It’s difficult to get change when you’re travelling,” he said. 
Ikano Power Centre’s Halasuria Money Changer staff said wholesalers now only sold Rs2,000 rupee notes although they had smaller denominations as and when they bought some from the public. 
A SkyXChange moneychanger staff, who wanted to be identified as Mohd, said while moneychangers used to sell notes as low as Rs100 and Rs500 rupees, they could now only offer the Rs2,000 rupee notes. 
In Johor Baru, The Star found that many moneychangers had yet to get the new rupee banknotes or were relying on people returning from India to change their notes. 
Eastern Union F.X. Sdn Bhd partner Rahman Ibrahim said it had to turn down many customers wanting to buy the new rupee banknotes because they have no new stock. 
“We were informed by our colleagues in India that the new Rs500 and Rs2,000 rupees are already in circulation there.”
